info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 03 at 4:36PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1030 PM EDT THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Nuisance to Minor flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of upstate South Carolina, including the following counties, Greenville and Pickens. * WHEN...Until 1030 PM EDT Thursday. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Dangerous flows over low-water crossings. Some low-water crossings may become impassable. River or stream flows are elevated. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 428 PM EDT, Doppler radar and raingauges are indicating an axis of training heavy showers are impacting portions of northeast Pickens and northern Greenville counties. Between 1-3 inches of rainfall has occurred over the past 2-3 hours on top of rainfall from earlier this morning. This is going to cause significant rises on small streams in the Advisory area, especially along Oolenoy River. Areas of greatest flood concern include along and near Table Rock Rd, Oolenoy Church Rd, Dalton Rd, Pace Bridge Rd, and Pumpkintown Hwy. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected over the area. Given saturated soils, more significant flooding could occur and a Flash Flood Warning may be required. Please stay weather aware and be prepared to seek higher ground. It is best to avoid all low-lying areas for the next several hours in case flooding develops and worsens. - Some locations that may experience flooding include... Travelers Rest, Slater-Marietta, Cherrydale Point, Lake Robinson, Table Rock State Park, Jocassee Gorges, Dacusville, Cleveland, Pumpkintown, Sassafras Mountain, Sunset and Rocky Bottom. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
